Package org.jtrim2.stream

Interface SeqProducer<T>

Type Parameters:
T - the type of the produced elements
public interface SeqProducer<T>
Defines a source of a sequence of elements. If you wish to provide multiple sequences of elements, then consider using SeqGroupProducer. The producer may or may not be reusable depending on the implementation. If the producer is defined to be reusable, then it should produce the same elements every time it is requested for the sequence (of course, if the source is an external source that is not always enforceable).

Note that this interface can be conveniently implemented by a lambda. For example: 


 Path srcFile = ...;
 SeqProducer<String> producer = (cancelToken, consumer) -> {
   try (BufferedReader source = Files.newBufferedReader(srcFile, StandardCharsets.UTF_8)) {
     String line;
     while ((line = source.readLine()) != null) {
       cancelToken.checkCanceled();
       consumer.processElement(transformJob(line, "reader"));
     }
   }
 };
The above example code provides the lines of a file in order, while properly opening the file exactly once before processing, and the closing it as appropriate.

Thread safety

The thread-safety property of this interface are completely implementation dependent.

Synchronization transparency

Implementations of this interface are not required to be synchronization transparent.
See Also:
  • SeqGroupProducer

  • Method Details

    • empty

      static <T> SeqProducer<T> empty()
      Returns a producer producing zero elements (i.e., it will never make a call to the consumer).

      The returned producer is reusable any number of times.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the produced elements
      Returns:
      a producer producing zero elements (i.e., it will never make a call to the consumer). This method never returns null.

    • flatteningProducer

      static <T> SeqProducer<T> flatteningProducer(SeqProducer<? extends Iterable<? extends T>> src)
      Returns a producer producing the elements of the Iterable instances produced by the given producer. For example, if the given producer produces is [[0, 1, 2], [3, 4]], then the returned producer will produce [0, 1, 2, 3, 4].

      The returned producer is reusability is the same as the producer given in the argument.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the element produced by the returned producer
      Parameters:
      src - the source producer producing Iterable instances to be flattened. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a producer producing the elements of the Iterable instances produced by the given producer. This method never returns null.
      See Also:
      • FluentSeqProducer.apply
      • FluentSeqProducer.batch

    • copiedArrayProducer

      @SafeVarargs static <T> SeqProducer<T> copiedArrayProducer(T... src)
      Returns a producer producing the elements given in the argument. If you explicitly pass an array as an argument, then the array is copied, and changes to the array will not affect the returned producer.

      The returned producer is reusable any number of times.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the produced elements
      Parameters:
      src - the elements to be produced by the returned producer (in order). This argument cannot be null, and since these streams do not support null elements, it must not contain null elements.
      Returns:
      a producer producing the elements given in the argument. This method never returns null.

    • arrayProducer

      static <T> SeqProducer<T> arrayProducer(T[] src)
      Returns a producer producing the elements given in the argument. The given array is not copied, so changes to the passed array will affect the returned producer.

      The returned producer is reusable any number of times.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the produced elements
      Parameters:
      src - the elements to be produced by the returned producer (in order). This argument cannot be null, and since these streams do not support null elements, it must not contain null elements.
      Returns:
      a producer producing the elements given in the argument. This method never returns null.

    • iterableProducer

      static <T> SeqProducer<T> iterableProducer(Iterable<? extends T> src)
      Returns a producer producing the elements given in the argument. The given Iterable is not copied, so changes to the passed Iterable will affect the returned producer.

      The returned producer is reusable any number of times.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the produced elements
      Parameters:
      src - the elements to be produced by the returned producer (in order). This argument cannot be null, and since these streams do not support null elements, it must not contain null elements.
      Returns:
      a producer producing the elements given in the argument. This method never returns null.

    • forEachableProducer

      static <T> SeqProducer<T> forEachableProducer(ForEachable<? extends T> src)
      Returns a producer producing the elements given in the argument. The given ForEachable is not copied, so changes to the passed ForEachable will affect the returned producer.

      The returned producer is reusable any number of times.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the produced elements
      Parameters:
      src - the elements to be produced by the returned producer (in order). This argument cannot be null, and since these streams do not support null elements, it must not contain null elements.
      Returns:
      a producer producing the elements given in the argument. This method never returns null.

    • transferAll

      void transferAll(CancellationToken cancelToken, ElementConsumer<? super T> consumer) throws Exception
      Passes all the underlying elements to the provided consumer in order. Note that an empty producer will never invoke the given consumer. This method must assume that the provided consumer is no longer usable once this method returns.

      Exceptions thrown by the provided consumer must be propagated to the caller, and must not be wrapped (with the exception of checked exceptions not implementing Exception).

      Parameters:
      cancelToken - the cancellation token which should be checked if the processing is to be canceled before completing the whole processing. There is no guarantee that the implementation will detect the cancellation request, but a well-behaved implementation should make a best effort check, if it does some lengthy operation. If cancellation was detected by this call, then it must respond by throwing an OperationCanceledException. This argument cannot be null.
      consumer - the consumer to which the elements are to be passed to in the order of underlying sequence. This argument cannot be null.
      Throws:
      OperationCanceledException - thrown if cancellation of the stream processing was detected by this method call
      Exception - thrown if there was a processing failure. This usually means that the whole processing of the stream is to be discontinued.

    • toFluent

      default FluentSeqProducer<T> toFluent()
      Returns a convenient fluent builder to create a complex producer starting out from this producer.

      Implementation note: This method has an appropriate default implementation, and there is normally no reason to override it.

      Returns:
      a convenient fluent builder to create a complex producer. This method never returns null.
